content:
I've edited the statement based on the comment in the forum ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-hangman/2172/13 ).

Goal
* Added: "in a case-insensitive manner. That means, an input letter is considered a correct guess regardless of case."

Input
* Added "[[chars]] for".

* Added "English".

Output
* Changed "characters" to "letters".

Constraints
* Added "[[entry]] contains uppercase and lowercase English letters and spaces only."

* Changed "len([[entry]])" to "length([[entry]])".

* Changed "len(list of chars)" to "number of letters in [[chars]]".

Difficulty
* Changed from "Hard" to "Medium" in view of the current success rate of 71% (could be even lower, but I'll just lower one level for now).
Added "write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

You should not propose a letter more than once.
Just propose letters that do not appear.
Please also describe exactly the order how to build the hangman, especially when there is no error because I know this game with the gallows counting for three or four errors: one for the big vertical pole, one for the horizontal one and one for the rope (and one for the diagonal pole).

I changed the wording, the 7 possible representations are all given to avoid confusion. 

For multiple occurences of the same letter, I stand on my position : the player should be allowed to do it.
Didn't know you can also change level difficulty when editing a puzzle :) No wonder it I found one of my solved puzzles missing in the **HARD** category ^^
Yes, though I don't want to change difficulty too much as it can be quite subjective.
I don't quite understand your reply on the forum. Would you please send me a PM there as per your suggestion?

I'm fine with the player being stupid and trying the same letter over and over.

What I'm not fine with is the moderator letting the player attempt new letters after they missed 6 already (that's the "wrong answer" test and validator).

Fixing that (for reference: extra letter used to be a w) and wording (word/sentence ambiguity, typography, constraints), and validating.

Edit: the extra letters also plagued the final test/validator.
That's fine with me, even if I don't see what's wrong. As soon as there are more than 6 errors, the moderator has to stop anyway.

To elaborate: what was wrong to me is that the statement says: "at the 6th mistake, the game is over". Putting more letters than 6 errors means the moderator has let the player continue to provide letters after the game is over. To which one could obviously object "why not?", but IMHO if the I/O let you play the game after the game is over, it needs more warning than that.
One could also argue for an asynchronous player/moderator link, but, really, no one plays hangman like that.

To present differently: letters after 6 errors are invalid games. Usually community puzzles try and guarantee valid settings. The common exception is when detecting invalid settings is an interesting part of the problem, but that isn't the case here IMHO. As a telltale sign, no specific "INVALID GAME" output is requested.
